questions.text: The study of social problems in the society can be grouped in all except
questions.solution:
The study of social problems in society is dealt with by social pathology. These can be grouped in three categories: (l) social constraints, (2) social evils, and (3) social deviance.

Social Defense

  • It is inclusive of preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services that help protect the society from anti-social or criminal elements. It is focused on the marginalized groups which need social protection of some sort.
  • For example, the provision of juvenile homes for delinquents, the old age homes, de-addiction centers, etc.

Topic- Social Medicine

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 6, Page no. 59-60

questions.text: 12-year-old Maya has lived with her grandmother since her parents divorced three years ago. While her grandmother provides for her basic needs. Which type of family is this?
questions.solution:
A family of procreation describes one that is formed through marriage.

Based on size or structure family can be classified into two main types:

  1. Nuclear or primary family:
    • Consists of two generations consisting of parents and their own or adopted children living in the same household.
    • child-rearing responsibilities solely rely on husband and wife as no grandparents or uncle and aunts are present.
    • The relationship between husband and wife is more intimate compared to joint family.
  2. Joint family:
    • This may be three generation family, or lateral extended family.
    • All responsibilities are shared among all family members, which provides a greater economic and social security to family.
    • Also provides economic and social security to the old, and the unemployed.

Based on the nature of authority family can be classified into two main types:

  1. Matriarchal:
    • Family headed by females, found among the Nairs of Malabar, the Khasis and Garos of Meghalaya
  2. Patriarchal:
    • A family headed by a male

Based on the nature of relations family can be classified into two main types:

  1. Conjugal family - consists of a sexual relationship between adult members.
  2. Consanguine family - consists of blood relationship among members-brother and sister, father, and son, etc.

Symmetrical family in which couples share domestic work between themselves.

Reconstituted family in which one or both partners were previously married or partnered, with children from previous marriages or partnerships.

Cohabitation-a household comprising of two people who live together, without marriage on a long-term basis in a relationship.

Broken family

  • these are families where parents are separated or divorced.
  • Children live with one of the parents, or many a time they are looked after by one of the grandparents due to death of one or both the parents.

Problem families

  • problem families are troubled families who lag the rest of the community.
  • There are usually many children who may be feeble-minded, quality of life is lower than expected and parents are unable to meet the physical and emotional needs of their children.
  • They usually require care, supervision, and support for their well-being as they are socially defective.
  • Commonly belong to the lower social classes.

New family-this is a family of less than 10 years duration and consists of parents and children. This concept is important in family planning studies.

Redefining of family- People related by marriage, birth, consanguinity, or legal adoption, who share a common kitchen and financial resources on a regular basis.

Topic- Social Medicine

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 6, Page no. 66-67

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 7, Page no. 94

choices.text: The organism must be observed in every case of the disease
It must be isolated and grown in pure culture
The pure culture must, when inoculated into a susceptible animal, not necessary to reproduce the disease
The organism must be observed in, and recovered from, the experimental animal

questions.text: Which one of these is NOT true for Koch's postulates?
questions.solution:
Robert Koch summarized in his four postulates how to ascertain diseases to specific causative organisms.

  1. The organism must be observed in every case of the disease.
  2. It must be isolated and grown in pure culture
  3. The pure culture must, when inoculated into a susceptible animal, reproduce the disease
  4. Ihe organism must be observed in, and recovered from, the experimental animal.

Koch's postulates were criticized on certain grounds, but till date it remains the backbone of the 'causation theory' of communicable diseases. For non-communicable diseases, Framingham Heart Study provided the much-needed breakthrough.

Topic- History of medicine

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 15, Page no. 221-222.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Roentgen: One roentgen is that amount of X-ray or gamma radiation that will deposit enough energy to strip about two billion electrons from their orbits (called one electrostatic unit) in 1 mL of dry air.

RAD (Radiation absorbed dose): RAD is a measure of the absorbed dose per gram of body tissue or material.

REM: Term for dose equivalence and equals the biological damage that would be caused by 1 RAD of dose.

(That is, the damage from 1 RAD deposited by beta-radiation is less than that caused by 1 RAD of alpha-radiation. The REM is numerically equal to the dose in RADs multiplied by a quality factor, which accounts for the difference in the amount of biological damage caused by the different types of radiation).

One Curie is defined as the amount of radioactive material that decays at the rate of 37 billion disintegrations per second.

Gray is the SI unit of absorbed dose. 1 Gray is equal to 1 Joule of energy deposited in one kilogram of matter.

Sievert is the SI unit of dose equivalent. In the same way as converting from the absorbed dose (RAD) to the dose equivalent (REM) involved the use of quality factors, the conversion of gray to sievert uses quality factors.

Topic- Environment

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 7, Page no. 74.

questions.text:
You are a public health official working in India, and you are analyzing national population data. You have observed that the birth rate and death rate have both been declining for the past few decades, but the birth rate is still higher than the death rate. As a result, the population of India is steadily increasing.
Questions:
Which stage of the demographic transition model best describes the current population situation in India?
questions.solution:
Late expanding (third stage): During this stage, birth rate starts declining while death rate starts declining more. Population of country is increasing due to a greater number of births then deaths. India has entered in this phase. India's current birth rate and death rates are showing declining trend but still birth rate exceeds death rate.

Topic- Family Planning and Demography

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 12, Page no. 200

questions.text: The number of live births per thousand women in the reproductive age group in a year refers to
questions.solution:
General Fertility Rate (GFR):

  • It is the number of live births women in the 15-44 or 49 years in a given year.
  • It is a better measure of fertility than the CBR because the denominator restricted to the number of women in the Childbearing age rather than the Whole population.
  • The major weakness of this rate is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to the risk of childbirth.

Total fertility rate (TFR):

  • Average no. of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing same rates as the women now group.
  • Computed by summing the age-specific-fertility rates for all ages; if 5 year age groups are used, the sum of the rates is multiplied by 5.
  • gives the approximate magnitude of "completed family size".

Net reproduction rate:

Gross reproduction rate:

Topic- Family Planning and Demography

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 8, Page No. 563

questions.text: Anthrax belongs to which category of bioterrorism Agent?
questions.solution:
Category A bioterrorism Agent

  • can be easily disseminated
  • high mortality rate
  • public panic and disruption seen
  • require special action for public health preparedness

Category B:

  • second highest priority agents
  • agents which are moderately easy to disseminate
  • cause moderate and low mortality rates and require specific diagnostic capacity and upgraded disease surveillance.

Category C:

  • Third priority agents
  • comprise of emerging pathogens that could be engineered for massive destruction in the future.
  • easily available, easier to be produced and disseminated but also have capacity to cause huge public health impact.

Topic- International health, bioterrorism Agent

questions.text: Headquarter of this international agency is in ?
questions.solution:
International health agency:

Topic- International health, Health Agency

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 25, Page No. 1030

questions.text: Early pioneer of immunization is?
questions.solution:
Chinese Medicine

Chinese medicine is considered one of the oldest organized forms of medical knowledge, dating back to 2700 B.C. It revolves around the principles of yang and yin, representing active masculine and negative feminine forces. The balance of these opposites is believed to lead to good health.

In ancient China, physicians focused on maintaining health through practices like hygiene, dietetics, hydrotherapy, massage, and herbal drugs. Interestingly, the Chinese were early pioneers of immunization, using variolation to prevent smallpox.

To the Chinese, a "great doctor" wasn't just someone who treated the sick but someone who prevented illness in the first place. This preventive approach is still integrated into modern Chinese medicine, including the widely recognized "barefoot doctors" system and acupuncture.

In recent years, Chinese medicine has gained global attention for its holistic approach to health and its integration with modern healthcare practices.

Indian Medicine

India has two native medical systems, Ayurveda and Siddha. Ayurveda, meaning "knowledge of life," dates back to 5000 B.C. and has roots in Vedic times. Figures like Dhanvantari and Atreya played crucial roles, and Ayurveda flourished under Buddhist rule. Charaka compiled the "Charaka Samhita" around 200 A.D., listing numerous drugs. Rauwolfia, used for centuries to treat hypertension, is an example of Ayurvedic influence before modern medicine.

Sushruta's "Sushruta Samhita" laid the foundation for Indian surgery, and Ayurveda emphasizes balancing three humors for health. Ancient Indian laws like the Manu Smriti emphasized personal hygiene. Archaeological findings in Mohenjo-daro and Harappa highlight advanced sanitation in the Indus Valley civilization.

The golden age of Ayurveda (800 BC - 600 AD) saw significant advancements, but it declined during the Moghul period. Ayurveda shares similarities with Greek medicine, both influencing neighboring regions. Unani-Tibb, introduced around the 10th century AD, originated from Greek medicine, while Homeopathy gained popularity in India in the 18th-19th centuries.

Despite historical changes, Ayurveda, Unani-Tibb, and Homeopathy continue to be practiced in India. They are deeply rooted in Indian culture and remain crucial for medical care, especially in rural areas. These traditional systems play a significant role in India's diverse healthcare landscape.

Egyptian Medicine

Ancient Egypt, dating back to around 2000 BCE, showcased advanced medical practices that were well-documented due to their innovative use of picture writing and papyrus scrolls. Medicine was closely linked with religion, and physicians received training in temple schools, often working alongside priests. Despite religious restrictions on anatomy, specialization in various medical fields was common and supported by the state.

Egyptian medicine demonstrated a sophisticated understanding of diseases, attributing them to harmful substances in the gut. Treatment methods included cathartics, enemas, bloodletting, and diverse drugs. Notable medical texts like the Edwin Smith papyrus and Ebers papyrus detailed surgical techniques and drug prescriptions.

In public health, Egyptians excelled, implementing advanced sanitation measures, constructing public baths, and developing underground drainage systems. They practiced rudimentary inoculation against smallpox, recognized the importance of mosquito nets, and associated plagues with rats. Their dominance in medicine persisted for about 2,500 years, eventually giving way to Greek medicine. Ancient Egypt's contributions continue to influence medical practices and understanding of diseases.

Greek Medicine

During the classic period of Greek medicine (460-136 B.C.), the Greeks were recognized as civilizers of the ancient world, emphasizing critical thinking in terms of "Why" and "How." A key figure was Aesculapius, with his daughters Hygiea and Panacea symbolizing health and medicine. This led to the division between curative medicine and preventive medicine, a dichotomy still present today.

Hippocrates (460-370 B.C.), often called the "Father of Medicine," played a significant role. Born on the island of Cos, he challenged magical traditions in medicine and introduced a clinical approach, compiling his teachings into the Hippocratic Corpus. The Hippocratic Oath became a cornerstone of medical ethics, emphasizing integrity.

Hippocrates was not only a great physician but also an early epidemiologist, distinguishing between epidemic and endemic diseases. The Greeks departed from supernatural theories, viewing disease as a natural process related to humoral imbalances. Although the humoral theory was flawed, the concept of the body's innate capacity for restoration remains relevant in modern medicine.

Post-Hippocratic, Alexandria's museum, the first university, flourished, hosting a vast library and becoming a center of learning. The Hippocratic school influenced Alexandria and later Arabo-Persian medicine, separating medicine from magic and elevating it to a scientific status. With the decline of Greek civilization, Roman civilization emerged, marking a transition in the history of medicine.

Topic- History of medicine

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 1, Page No. 2-3

questions.text: Which color-coded bag is intended for expired or discarded medicines?
questions.solution:
Yellow color-coded bag -Human anatomical waste, animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, microbiology. biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste

Red color-coded bag -Plastic waste such as tubing. bottles. intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes) and vacutainers (with their needles cut) and gloves.

Blue color-coded bag -Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes and metallic body implants.

White color-coded bag -Sharp waste including metals like needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle trip cutter or burner, scalpels. blades, etc.

Topic- BMW

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd edition, Chapter 34, page 731

choices.text: The role of sanitation in disease prevention
The relationship between miasma and typhoid fever
The transmission of typhoid fever through water

questions.text: What was the primary focus of William Budd's observations?
questions.solution:
• In 1856, William Budd, a medical pioneer, made careful observations of a typhoid fever outbreak in rural northern England.
  • He concluded that the disease spread through contaminated drinking water, not through miasma (bad air) or sewer gas as previously believed.
  • William Budd "concluded that the spread (of typhoid fever) was by drinking water, not by miasma and sewer gas". This directly highlights his focus on waterborne transmission.
  • Option a ("The role of sanitation in disease prevention") is relevant to Budd's work as clean water is central to sanitation, but it's not the specific subject of his observations.
  • Option b ("The relationship between miasma and typhoid fever") is incorrect because Budd challenged the miasma theory and argued against it as a cause of typhoid.
  • Option d ("Study the epidemiology of Cholera") is incorrect because John Snow, a pioneering English epidemiologist, meticulously studied cholera outbreaks in London between 1848 and 1854. His groundbreaking work revealed the link between contaminated drinking water and the spread of cholera.

Topic: History of medicine

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 1, Page No. 5

choices.text: Advocated the intake of fresh fruit and vegetable for the prevention of scurvy
Known as a father of public health

questions.text: Choose the statement that describes something James Lind accomplished:
questions.solution:
James Lind's key accomplishment was conducting one of the first controlled clinical trials in medical history. He identified scurvy, a common and debilitating disease among sailors, and through observation and experimentation, demonstrated that consuming citrus fruits was an effective cure. This discovery revolutionized naval health practices and significantly reduced the prevalence of scurvy at sea.

b) Discovered vaccination against smallpox: This was achieved by Edward Jenner in 1796.

c) Studied cholera outbreaks in London: This was the work of John Snow in the mid-19th century, distinct from Lind's research on scurvy in the 18th century.

d) Known as a father of public health: the title "father of public health" is more often associated to Cholera

Topic: History of medicine

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 1, Page No. 6

choices.text: The art and science of Health promotion and specific protection.
The science and art of preventing diseases, prolonging life, and promoting physical and mental health and improving efficiency.
The art and science of diagnosing illnesses.
The art and science of advancing medical research.

questions.text: Which statement most accurately defines preventive medicine?
questions.solution:
• Leavell and Clark defined preventive medicine as "the science and art of preventing diseases, prolonging life and promoting physical and mental health and improving efficiency".
  • In essence and principle, it embodies "all medicine that seeks to alter the course of diseases or to better patient's physiological status", thus including all measures that protect, promote, and maintain health and well-being and prevent disease, disability, and death.
  • It helps in managing the health of the individuals, communities and defined population.
  • Main aim of preventive medicine is to achieve a diseases free state, which can be attained either by stopping occurrence of a disease or by halting a disease progress and deterring resulting complications after its onset.
  • Preventive medicine can be practiced by governmental agencies, healthcare physicians and by individuals themselves.
  • In present scenario when different countries of world are facing ever increasing challenge of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular diseases, etc., over and above existing communicable diseases [diarrhea, malaria, dengue tuberculosis (TB), etc.), it becomes very important and essential that preventive strategies are practiced at wider scale against these diseases for saving lives of people, prolonging disease free life span and minimizing cost for disease management.

Topic: History of medicine

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 124

choices.text: They are performed primarily on people with no apparent health issues.
They are typically applied to specific groups, such as by age or risk factors.
Their results are considered definitive and non-negotiable.
They do not directly inform treatment decisions.

questions.text: Which statement about screening tests is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
1. They are performed primarily on people with no apparent health issues. (True: This is a defining characteristic of screening tests.)
  2. They are typically applied to specific groups, such as by age or risk factors. (True: Targeting relevant populations improves efficiency and effectiveness.)
  3. Their results are considered definitive and non-negotiable. (False: Positive results often warrant further diagnostic testing for confirmation.)
  4. They do not directly inform treatment decisions. (True: Positive screening results usually lead to more specific diagnostic tests, which then guide treatment.)

Topic: Screening

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 131

questions.text: A researcher is studying two diagnostic tests for disease X. Test A has a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 90%, while Test B has a sensitivity of 75% and a specificity of 95%. The researcher wants to combine the tests to achieve the best possible balance of sensitivity and specificity. Which formula would correctly calculate the parallel sensitivity of the combined tests?
questions.solution:
This formula accurately calculates the parallel sensitivity using the provided information about individual test sensitivities.

Combined sensitivity and specificity can be achieved through following formulas:

Sensitivity and specificity in serial and parallel testing

Here, Test A has a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 90% and Test B has a sensitivity of 75% and a specificity of 95%.

To calculate the parallel sensitivity of the combined tests following formula will be used.

Sensitivity (parallel) = 1 - (1 - sensitivity test A) x (1- sensitivity test B) = 1-(1-0.8) x (1-0.75)

(a) 0.9 * 0.95 this gives Specificity (parallel)= specificity test A x specificity test B

(c) 0.8 * 0.75 this gives Sensitivity (series)= sensitivity test A x sensitivity test B

(d) 1 - (1-0.9) *(1- 0.95) this gives Specificity (series) = 1 - (1 - specificity test A) x (1 - specificity test B)

Topic: Screening

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 136

questions.text: Solid wastes contains all except?
questions.solution:
"Solid wastes" includes:

  • garbage (food wastes)
  • rubbish (paper, plastics, wood, metal, throw-away containers, glass),
  • demolition products (bricks, masonry, pipes),
  • sewage treatment residue (sludge and solids from the coarse screening of domestic sewage),
  • dead animals,
  • manure and other discarded material

It should not contain nightsoil.

Reference: K Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 15, Page no. 881

questions.text: A physician, after examining a group of patients of a certain disease, classifies the condition of each one as normal, mild, moderate and severe. Which one of the following is the scale of measurement that is being adopted for classification of the disease condition?
questions.solution:
4 different scale of measurement: NOIR

Nominal (N) - categorization

Ordinal (O) - rank ordering

Interval (I) - interval ordering

Ratio (R) - numerical scoring

  • Nominal scale:
    • data are divided into qualitative groups or categories but not ranked
    • Example - male/female, hindu/muslim, right/left, blood group A/B/O, ICD 11
    • Only mode can be applied in nominal scale
  • Ordinal scale: putting things in order, like "no pneumonia", "pneumonia", and "severe pneumonia".
  • We can say which is worse than another, but not how much worse.
  • It's like saying someone is taller than another, but not how much taller.
  • This scale is simple, just high to low, useful for things like grades or severity of illness.
  • Interval scale
    • Similar to ordinal but data are placed in meaningful order and also have definite intervals between them which can be measured.
    • Does not have absolute zero
    • Example - temperature, IQ
  • Ratio scale:
    • Same as interval scale but it includes absolute zero

Among the three ordered scales, i.e. ordinal, interval and ratio scale, ordinal scale occupies the lowest level e.g. ordinal < interval < ratio. Thus, ordinal scale is the lowest ordered scale and ratio scale is the highest ordered scale.

Topic: Biostate and research

Reference: Essential of Biostatistics & Research Methodology Indranil Saha & Bobby Paul, 3rd Edition, Chapter 2, Page no. 37

questions.text: Identify the statistical diagram shown in photograph.
questions.solution:
Stem and leaf plot

  • This diagram is said to be a mixture of diagram and table.
  • shows the shape of the data according to the data place values.
  • The leaf of a number is usually the last digit in a number and the stem is the remaining digit or digits to the left.
  • The stem is separated from the leaf by a vertical line. Stem items are either arranged in ascending or descending order vertically.
  • The number of leaf items should add up to the total number of observations.
  • The stem is used to group the data values and each leaf shows the individual value within each group.
  • This diagram preserves the individual values of the variable.
  • Can be easily drawn by hand without the use of any statistical software or excel.
  • More effective with relatively small data sets.

Funnel plot

  • Studies with negative results are less likely to be published, so we are going to miss findings of these studies though results of those studies are also important.
  • So, missing of these studies is called as publication bias.
  • To overcome and check the likely presence of publication bias we draw the funnel plot
  • Funnel plot: funnel plot displays the studies included in the meta-analysis in a plot which is drawn for effect size against sample size.
  • As smaller studies have more chances of variability than larger studies, the expected shape of funnel plot is inverted funnel plot (which is normal). If it is asymmetrical that means we may have missed some trials usually some smaller studies.
  • In absence of bias symmetrical plot.
  • In presence of bias asymmetrical plot (region without circle is the region of missing study)
  • In the presence of bias due to low methodological quality of smaller studies asymmetrical plot.

limitation of funnel plot

  • Asymmetry of plot is to be assessed by eye which is subjective and difficult.
  • To overcome this limitation egger's regression test (to taste publication bias).
  • It tastes weather small studies tend to have large effect sizes than would be expected.

Forest plot

  • Results of each study shown as blog or square. If squares are towards the left side means treatment is effective.
  • Size of all square is proportional to the sample size of that particular study.
  • Length of line (horizontal) shows confidence interval.
  • Aggregate result of effect size by combining all the studies is usually displaced as a diamond. If confidence interval of any particular study crosses 1 then the result is not significant

Box and Whisker plot

  • It is useful in comparing the distribution of two or more groups.
  • It is also known as five number summary which includes median, the lower quartile, upper quartile, and the smallest and greatest values in the distribution.
  • It displays the center, the spread, and the overall range of distribution.

Topic: Biostate and research

Reference: Essential of Biostatistics & Research Methodology Indranil Saha & Bobby Paul, 3rd Edition, Chapter 1, Page no. 21

questions.text:
You're a healthcare researcher working at a large hospital. You're concerned about the number of patients who seem to be discontinuing their prescribed treatments prematurely. To better understand the scope of this issue and identify potential interventions, you decide to conduct a research study.
Which type of research approach would be most appropriate for quantifying the prevalence of treatment defaulting among patients and exploring potential factors associated with it?
questions.solution:
Here the purpose is often to "estimate" a number (e.g., prevalence of patients defaulting on treatment). We use numbers to quantify the problem. So Quantitative research would be most appropriate for quantifying the prevalence of treatment defaulting among patients and exploring potential factors associated with it.

Topic: Biostate and research

Reference: Essential of Biostatistics & Research Methodology Indranil Saha & Bobby Paul, 3rd Edition, Chapter 12, Page no. 202-203

questions.text: What % of the population fall within 2 critical ratios?
questions.solution:
In a normally distributed data set:

68.27% (68.3%) population lies within 1 critical ratio (i.e. within mean * 1 SD)

95.45% (95.4%) population lies within 2 critical ratios (i.e. within mean # 2 SD)

99.73% (99.7%) population lies within 3 critical ratios (i.e. within mean + 3 SD)

Topic: Biostate and research

Reference: Essential of Biostatistics & Research Methodology Indranil Saha & Bobby Paul, 3rd Edition, Chapter 4, Page no. 65

questions.text: Diagnostic power of the test is reflected by
questions.solution:
Formulas:

Sensitivity = a/(a+c) x100

Specificity = d/(b+d) x 100

% of false negative: c/(a+c) x 100

% of false positive: b/(b+d) x 100

Predictive value of a positive test = a/(a+b) x100

Predictive value of a negative test = d/(c+d) x 100

  • The term sensitivity was introduced as a statistical index of diagnostic accuracy.
  • It has been defined as the ability of a test to correctly identify all those who have the disease, that is "true-positive".
  • A 90 percent sensitivity means that 90 per cent of the diseased people screened by the test will give a "true-positive" result and the remaining 10 per cent a "false-negative" result.

Topic: Screening

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 4, Page No. 154

questions.text: Out of 10,000 subjects screened by ELISA test, it was observed that 8840 showed negative result 1160 showed positive result. Disease was present in 200 subjects, out of which 180 showed positive test, Calculate the test which correctly identifies those who does not have the disease?
questions.solution:
We have to find out Specificity because It is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly

those who do not have the disease, that is, "true-negatives".

  • Sensitivity= a/(a+c) x100
  • Specificity= d/(b+d) x 100
  • % of false negative: c/(a+c) x 100
  • % of false positive: b/(b+d) x 100
  • Predictive value of a positive test = a/(a+b) x100
  • Predictive value of a negative test = d/(c+d) x 100

Formula = True negative/True negative + False positive

Given, 10,000 subjects

200 had disease, so 9800 no disease

180 got Tested Positive

20 got False Negative

8840 Tested Negative -8820 True Negative


= 8820/8820+980

= 8820/9800 = 0.98 x 100

= 90%

Topic- Screening

Reference- K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 4, Page No.155
